DataElement.preferredName: Central Nervous System Neoplasm Histopathologic Grade Grade CNSHistologicGradeVD
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Central Nervous System Neoplasm Histopathologic Grade Grade
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Abnormal growth of cells that comprise the tissues of the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord), without designation of benign or malignant nature.:The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior_Describes how closely a cancer resembles normal tissue of its same type, and the cancer's probable rate of growth

ObjectClass.preferredName: Central Nervous System Neoplasm Histopathologic Grade
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Abnormal growth of cells that comprise the tissues of the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord), without designation of benign or malignant nature.:The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior

Concepts.definition: A benign or malignant, primary or metastatic neoplasm that affects the brain, meninges, or spinal cord.  Representative examples of primary neoplasms include astrocytoma, oligodendroglioma, ependymoma, and meningioma.  Representative examples of metastatic neoplasms include carcinoma and leukemia.

The degree of abnormality of cancer cells, a measure of differentiation, the extent to which cancer cells are similar in appearance and function to healthy cells of the same tissue type. The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

Property.preferredDefinition: Describes how closely a cancer resembles normal tissue of its same type, and the cancer's probable rate of growth

The degree of differentiation often relates to the clinical behavior of the particular tumor. Based on the microscopic findings, tumor grade is commonly described by one of four degrees of severity. Histopathologic grade of a tumor may be used to plan treatment and estimate the future course, outcome, and overall prognosis of disease. Certain types of cancers, such as soft tissue sarcoma, primary brain tumors, lymphomas, and breast have special grading systems.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Permissible values for CNSHistologicGradeVD_A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: WHO Central Nervous System Grade I

ValueMeaning.preferredName: WHO Central Nervous System Grade I
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes central nervous system tumors that are generally low malignancy, non-infiltrative, and slow growing. Often they can be cured by surgery alone and there is a good chance of long term survival.

Concepts.definition: Describes central nervous system tumors that are generally low malignancy, non-infiltrative, and slow growing. Often they can be cured by surgery alone and there is a good chance of long term survival.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: WHO Central Nervous System Grade II

ValueMeaning.preferredName: WHO Central Nervous System Grade II
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A suffix denoting the second person having the same complete name (first, middle, and family names).

Concepts.definition: Describes central nervous system tumors that are generally relatively slow growing and somewhat infiltrative. They may recur after treatment.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: WHO Central Nervous System Grade III

ValueMeaning.preferredName: WHO Central Nervous System Grade III
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes central nervous system tumors that are generally malignant and infiltrative. They tend to recur after treatment.

Concepts.definition: Describes central nervous system tumors that are generally malignant and infiltrative. They tend to recur after treatment.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: WHO Central Nervous System Grade IV

ValueMeaning.preferredName: WHO Central Nervous System Grade IV
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Describes central nervous system tumors that are generally highly malignant, show rapid and aggressive growth, widely infiltrative, and prone to necrosis. They often recur rapidly after treatment.

Concepts.definition: Describes central nervous system tumors that are generally highly malignant, show rapid and aggressive growth, widely infiltrative, and prone to necrosis. They often recur rapidly after treatment.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Top level term which includes Biological Markers, Risk Factors, and Prognostic Factors.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.

Concepts.definition: A position on a scale of intensity or amount or quality.
